bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Domingo F. Ramos, November 20, 1952

div1.p: Hench looks forward to renewing his friendship with Ramos, whom he assigned a central role in the preservation of Camp Lazear. Hench also hopes that Ramos' suggestion of a public health facility on the site might be carried out, and pledges his support in this effort.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Domingo F. Ramos, November 20, 1952
div1.opener:
November 20, 1952
Dr. Domingo F. Ramos
Calle 28, No. 62
Miramar, Havana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Ramos:
div1.p:
As you of course know, at long last Camp Lazear is to be memorialized and
I and others have received invitations to the affair. The Surgeon General
of the U. S. Army has appointed General Paul H. Streit, Commanding General
of Walter Reed Hospital, to attend. The Mayo Foundation has authorized me
to attend as their official delegate.

I want you to know that even though others may, at the present time, be in
charge of affairs, I have no doubt that you have had a great deal to do
with it. I remember with great pleasure and satisfaction the little
paper which you wrote and published in 1939, “Monuments to the Memory of
the Heroes and Martyrs in the Struggle Against Yellow Fever.” I have
treasured this paper and particularly the sentiments expressed therein.
I shall expect to meet you at the dedication ceremonies and it will give
me great pleasure to renew our friendship.

Now that the little spot is being preserved, I am hoping indeed that your
original suggestion can be carried out, namely that on the spot can be
built a living memorial in the form of some sort of a building to serve
the people and the Public Health Department. I sincerely hope that I can
participate in this additional plan and enlist the generous support of
many Americans. Perhaps we will have a chance to talk about it in Cuba.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
